question: I don't know a recent Saturday I've sold more. You didn't think I'd sell that health restaurant, did you?
answer: No. Not even you.

question: Why so glum?
answer: I don't know.

question: Go ahead.
answer: No, nothing. I've got a problem, I guess.

question: Were you bothering by those waitresses making a fuss?
answer: No. But, honest. What are you supposed to say when they keep talking about your looks? I don't even know what they mean -- "Beat them off with a stick."

question: You know, Tom, I feel a little proud when people comment on your looks. Maybe you should feel that way.
answer: Proud? I'm just embarrassed that I like when they say those things.

question: As long as that's your only problem you're...
answer: It's not. I got my report card. Three Cs, two Ds and an incomplete.

question: Oh my. I see you studying so hard, Tom. What do you think the problem is?
answer: I'll just have to try harder. I don't know. I will. I will. I will. I will. Thanks, Dad, this talk helped. Will you sign it, please?

question: Would it help if I got you a tutor?
answer: That would be great. It better help. What can you do with yourself if all you do is look good?

question: Hi...It's me... There's probably no time to eat... but there's a cafeteria at the bus depot once we get down there. I love working with you two...It saves me a call.
answer: Hi. Turn on your TV... Good Morning America, the Morning News and Today are all about to talk to Arnold Schwarzenegger and I think he's live on at least two of them.

question: At six o'clock on the wake-up news they used the wrong missile graphic.
answer: Now listen, Arnold just said that he's been making three million a movie now. But he's not ever gonna change. He's still the same person when he was making two million dollars a movie. He feels no different. He also bought a brand- new condo with Maria, they gonna furnish tastefully.

question: A half hour in the lobby.
answer: Okay, I'll see you in the lobbies . Ready.

question: Okay, I'll see you in the lobbies . Ready.
answer: Your hair's a little funny.

question: It's an ethnic curl, I can't do anything about it.
answer: In front of a little -- it's a bit... You want a mirror?

question: No -- Don't worry about it. Let's do this.
answer: Okay.

question: In other times, with other purposes, there might be a band and bunting here at the bus depot for J.D. Singer's return from war. Last week he was decorated by a president for heroism in a war. But it was the civil war -- in Angola -- and he was in it for the money. Thanks. Just a few questions? We came from Washington. How long has it been since you've been home. It depends on how big a news day it is.
answer: J.D. I'm Jane Craig. I spoke to you in Angola. I gave you some sugarless gum and Handi-Wipes.

question: Where's where I asked him about being scared? You should work on your speech.
answer: No. It makes me nervous to think about it. Let's do this.

question: All this business of war -- do you get scared?
answer: I love that turn away. There's a point I'm trying to make about these pieces coming up. Please don't applaud. Please. Don't!! I gathered these pieces as an example of what's WRONG with local television news. The excerpts from THREE SEPARATE SERIES on prostitution were SIMULTANEOUSLY broadcast by all stations in one city during sweeps week. By what bend of either or suspension of duty is that broadcast news? The legacy of Edward R. Murrow, Eric Sevareid, William Shirer, David Brinkley and Walter Cronkite is being squandered in a desperate popularity contest. Our profession is in danger: Yesterday's compliment has somehow managed to become today's kiss of death. To be considered a serious journalist is no longer flattering. It presents the risk of being labeled ponderous, or worse yet, elitest, right?

question: All of you know what I'm talking about. We're all trying to act together than we are. But we care. So, we're all secretly terrified, aren't we? We are being increasingly influenced by the star system. The network anchormen are so powerful they compromise our last best hope. The current group is clearly qualified, tied still to our best traditions, but who follows these men?
answer: Wow.

question: I was going to talk about other trends but... ...the magazine shows, news at profit, influence of Entertainment Tonight, the danger, the hope, the dream, the question...Oh, I was going to show you a tape -- a story that was carried by all networks on the same night -- the same night -- not one network noted a major policy change in Salt Two nuclear disarmament talks... Here's what they ran instead...Go ahead. Show the tape. I know it's good film. I know it's fun. I like fun. It's just not news. Well, you're lucky you love it -- you're going to get a lot more just like it.
answer: Hello.

question: Hi.
answer: I just wanted to tell you how great you were. My name's Tom Grunick.

question: Thank you. They hated me. I don't hate them.
answer: Well, they say if you can reach even one person, it means something... And you did that.

question: Would you like to have dinner with me? Hi. I was worried I was early.
answer: I was a lot earlier. I kept thinking what a great break it was for me to get to see you tonight. More than a great break, maybe just what I needed...just when I needed it...Angel of mercy -- godsend...lifesaver...what?

question: I like "godsend."
answer: I haven't been in news that long. I've just been looking for the right person to talk to. I have about two thousand questions for you. It's possible now's not the right time.

question: If we could just eat first.
answer: Totally understood. Totally wrong of me to talk shop after the day you've had. Totally sorry.

question: Nooo. If I could just have a roll, I'd be okay. Thank you. Another thing I can't stand -- Is this dull?
answer: No, no, no, no...

question: Another thing I can't stand is ...when White House reporters bullshit with each other after a briefing and then one of them has a theory and the other quotes it in his story as "White House" sources say...
answer: That actually goes on...

question: Yes. My room is down here -- I'm not tired. Do you want to keep talking?
answer: Yes, sure.

question: Come on...Even I'm not that hard on myself.
answer: No, I really got this job on a fluke and wait till you hear where it ends up.

question: I was doing sports at the station. The newspaper ran this untrue story that I was leaving and they got all these tons of protest mail. So they made me anchor. So great -- right?
answer: Except I'm no good at what I'm being a success at.

question: How are you at back rubs? It's sort of normal -- the way you feel. In graduate school everyone thought the only mistake the admission committee made was letting them in.
answer: Listen to me. You keep on thinking I'm somebody ho lacks...confidence. That's not it. I know I can talk well enough and I'm not bad at making contact with people, but I don't like the feeling that I'm pretending to be a reporter. And half the time I don't really get the news I'm talking about. It isn't that I'm down on myself. Trust me, I stink.

question: I trust you.
answer: I didn't even have the chance to get really good at sports. I wasn't bad. I thought I was starting to do interesting features but hockey is big at the station and...

question: What about the obvious remedy? Reversing things. Maybe getting a job on a newspaper.
answer: I don't write. But that didn't stop me from sending out audition tapes to bigger stations and the networks.

question: Well, come on -- it is your life. Nobody is tying you to the fast track. Did you go to college?
answer: One year...almost one year.

question: So, you're not well educated and you have almost no experience and you can't write.
answer: And I'm making a fortune.

question: It's hard for me to advise you since you personify something that I truly think is dangerous.
answer: Uh-huh.

question: I agree with you -- you're not qualified. So get qualified. You can insist on being better prepared. You don't have to just leave it as... 'I don't write. I'm not schooled. I don't understand the news I'm reading. But at least I'm upset about it, folks.'
answer: Whoa, this was a mistake.

question: Just what do you want from me, anyway? Permission to be a fake? Stop whining and do something about it. Well, you don't have to start right now.
answer: I hated the way you talked to me just now...and it wasn't just because you were right.

question: No. It wasn't just the speech -- the same thing happened with this guy. I have passed some line some place. I am beginning to repel people I'm trying to seduce.
answer: He must have been great-looking, right?

question: Why do you say that?
answer: Because nobody invites a bad- looking idiot to their bedroom. Okay. Let's do me.

question: Sure.
answer: Okay. I feel like I'm slipping but do people who are actually slipping feel that way or is it always the really good people who are moving up who invariably think they're slipping because their standards are so high?

question: This conversation is not worthy of you.
answer: I'd give anything if that were true.

question: Good night.
answer: Wouldn't this be a great world if insecurity and desperation made us more attractive? If needy were a turn-on?

question: Call if you get weird. I was just thinking it was the shortest phone conversation we ever had.
answer: I never told you the reason I was telling you everything for.

question: Hey?
answer: Those audition tapes I sent out... I've been hired by your network for the Washington bureau. So I'll probably see you at work. Sorry.

question: Stop there. I want to shoot a picture from a book I have in the office.
answer: You don't have time. Not a chance.

question: I'll be right down. It's right tight.
answer: I've got to tell Ernie...because there isn't enough time.

question: I'm sorry if I was in the way. It was totally impressive. Great piece.
answer: You weren't. Thanks. How does it feel being here?

question: I can't believe I'm really here. No kidding. If you're through work now --
answer: No. Aaron and I go to Central America on Wednesday -- so I'm cramming.

question: I thought you were incredible in there. I know how much I have to learn. I'd really -- a lot -- appreciate it...if...
answer: 'Really a lot appreciate it...'

question: You make me nervous. Anyway if I can pick your brain --
answer: I can't help you, sorry. I'm not here to teach remedial reporting.

question: And it has nothing to do with the fact I left your room instead of staying there?
answer: Oh, please. You're gonna have to understand something. This isn't personal.

question: Oh, please. You're gonna have to understand something. This isn't personal.
answer: I didn't sleep. They're giving me less and less air time. They don't think I'm at all anchor material.

question: If we don't get to their camp soon, we won't be able to tape the supplies coming in.
answer: Last time Paul was sick they gave Connie the weekend news instead of me.

question: That's okay.
answer: The first shots were fired not thirty seconds ago. The Contras feel they must be outnumbered this is so small a unit

question: Okay. Great line at the end.
answer: Did you shoot their boots?

question: Of course.
answer: We can cut back at the end.

question: To the pan of the supplies boxes --
answer: Can you believe it? I just risked my life for a network that tests my face with focus groups.

question: Hi.
answer: How's it going?

question: Can I buy you dinner sometime soon?
answer: I just got back -- I don't know which end is up.

question: Jane?
answer: Yes.

question: Well, darling, if it gets any better than that, I'm going to have to bring you up here to New York.
answer: Thanks. I just wish you'd kept the first twenty seconds. But thanks.

question: Well, the visual with the boots at the end was just perfect.
answer: God, he loved the boots. Aaron should be hearing this so I have an extra witness.

question: Well, you always want to give the credit away, do you?
answer: No, I don't. He happens to deserve the credit. He's right here.

question: I'll speak to you soon
answer: He had to read over some new copy.

question: Could I see how I photograph? 'Cause for the interview they're going to use a screen and disguise me to protect my anonymity so could I see myself before that?
answer: It's Mr. Buddy Felton?

question: Yes.
answer: That's your full name?

question: Yes.
answer: I might as well ask you the questions on tape. Is that all right?

question: Yes.
answer: You worked at one time as Foreign Service Trainee in the State Department.

question: I was there two years and was promoted on merit nine times.
answer: Eventually rising to...

question: Office Bimbo. No, I'm sorry.
answer: You're saying the fact that you're gay had something directly to do with your promotions? Eventually rising to?

question: G.S. I don't know. I don't know numbers.
answer: You're saying the fact that you're gay had something directly to do with your promotions?

question: I don't like the word gay.
answer: Which would you prefer?

question: Ravenous homosexual.
answer: Stop the tape, okay. Forget it, Ellen. Let's call security and get him out.

question: Great time to act out, Buddy. You won't be happy until you turn the whole world off. They're not really going to call security are they?
answer: No, I don't think so.

question: How do I get out of here?
answer: Follow me.

question: You talked me into it. I'm leaving.
answer: It's okay.

question: Sir?
answer: Oh, sure. Okay.

question: Is there a regular bar around here?
answer: I've been doing some morning show stuff, but mostly radio -- that doesn't bother me. I'm in no rush for anything. It's just the snotty attitude, even if I have it coming, it's still...

question: Bad manners.
answer: Yes. That's right.

question: I know...I mean you didn't do anything special for me tonight. You just had what I think are good manners, decency. And it really makes me want to be nice back and it has nothing to do with any homosexual thing. Honestly. Because I don't know if you've homosexual or not and -- you're not, are you?
answer: No...no.

question: One's enough.
answer: I really have to go.

question: Okay. At least let me show my appreciation. The Secretary of Labor is going to be indicted on Wednesday. For the graft thing he supposedly did before he was appointed.
answer: What?

question: Yes, it's true. They're going to make it public Wednesday but isn't it a big deal for you to have it a day and a half early?
answer: Yes. How do you know?

question: ...and the White House is hoping to keep a lid on it for a few days till they figure out what to do.
answer: Thanks a lot, Buddy.

question: Oh, please. So they were really impressed with you at work.
answer: Not impressed exactly -- but a break in the clouds.

question: I see the change in you -- I see it.
answer: So he bought this Peugeot sedan at a greatly reduced price while he was there in charge of the White House Advance Team.

question: So he bought this Peugeot sedan at a greatly reduced price while he was there in charge of the White House Advance Team.
answer: How come you're not chasing it down yourself?

question: Look, I'm junior man -- and it's your beat.
answer: Boy, that's nice...I wish we could all deal with each other like this. I'll check it. Anything I can do for you?

question: This is my first time at the White House. Is there any chance to look at where he works and the rest of it?
answer: I didn't have the guts to ask when I first came up. I'll get you a great tour. The President says it's not a violation but nonetheless White House sources say the full price will be paid for the Peugeot and new rules will put future bargain hunting off limits for Presidential Aides. This is Jennifer Mack at the White House.

question: Forgive me, but it really is intoxicating being a news source.
answer: Nobody else had it.

question: I wish it were you giving the story.
answer: That's okay.

question: What if we just don't tell them anything anymore unless they let you do the story?
answer: No. Really...don't worry about it.

question: Okay. And look, in the future I can call you when I have news for you. Don't feel you have to spend time with me just to get the information. Well, that wasn't as hard to say as you thought, was it, Buddy?
answer: What do you mean? You're one of the few people in this town I can talk to.

question: Hoooo.
answer: Hey, Buddy, don't do that anymore.

question: Hi, how are you?
answer: Wait -- I need you. I've got another story.

question: Some public official skipped a week on his Christmas Club?
answer: The House Armed Service Committee has a secret report which says that the General Stillwell tank the Army has dumped a fortune into plain won't work. I have it cold, confirmed. They have five million dollars in this thing already.

question: Billion.
answer: Okay, billion...right, of course. They told me I could have any producer I wanted -- and I want you. One source referred to it as a five billion dollar metal sculpture to ugly to look at and too big to bury.

question: I don't know why we have to feel defensive about it. Newspapers are in business to make money -- why not us? They criticize us for supposedly pandering while they run WINGO Games. Goodbye, Paul.
answer: Take care, Paul. It takes a certain kind of courage for you to say that in front of the President of the News Division.

question: You think anyone who's proud of the work we do is an ass kisser.
answer: No. I think anyone who puckers their lips and presses it against his boss' buttocks and then smooches is an ass kisser.

question: My gosh, and for a while there, I was attracted to you.
answer: Wait a minute -- that changes everything.

question: This is very awkward.
answer: Go ahead -- what?

question: Ummm -- it's dumb dorm stuff but I see Tom around you a lot and this is such a small office and I'd like to see him outside of work, unless there's some reason for you to mind... in which case I just won't do anything.
answer: God Almighty -- Whew. Do I mind? Why do I mind? I do mind. What a shock -- I don't have a right to... I don't think I like him. I know I don't respect him...So what am I talking about -- what am I saying to you?

question: You're saying stay away from him.
answer: I can't be.

question: We don't have to settle this definitively right now.
answer: Hi, Tom.

question: Hi, Tom.
answer: It's the firs time I've seen you dressed like this. You look so clean and pretty.

question: What do you mean clean?
answer: At work there's always this sort of film over you.

question: Well, thumps like me leave appearance to guys like you.
answer: You're great at taking the edge off a good time. You okay?

question: This would be a good time to tap that source of yours. He could have an angle or something. We want you to exec produce a Special Report...
answer: What?

question: A Libyan plane shot up one of our bases in Egypt. It's all still happening.
answer: Let's figure out the field.

question: Tom isn't ready for the job you're about to hand him. Not near ready. Not by the longest shot. Aaron's spent six weeks in Tripoli, he's interviewed Gaddafi -- he reported on the Eight-one story. I think he's essential to do the job we're capable of and I think it's my responsibility to tell you that.
answer: Okay, that's your opinion. I don't agree.

question: It's not opinion.
answer: You're just absolutely right and I'm absolutely wrong? It must be nice to always believe you know better. To think you're always the smartest person in the room.

question: No, it's awful. Oh my, it's awful. We'd better get moving.
answer: What happened?

question: I'll tell you later -- where you going to watch from?
answer: Watch? --

question: I'll come by your place, right after...drink, take pills... Love you.
answer: Yeah, love you, too.

question: Tell George and Jessica to try and cover everything without Tom having to ask additional questions.
answer: And Bobbie says...

question: Did you hear what I just said -- do you have that? Take a breath.
answer: Yes.

question: Well, then check -- but hurry -- There he is!!! Is everything all right?
answer: Yes. You didn't have to come here. It's just that I'm going to anchor this special report on this Libyan thing...

question: Anchor?
answer: Yes, stop! I wondered if you could find out anything about what's happening. What's wrong?

question: I broke up with my roommate -- He was really the magnet for everyone who knew anything.
answer: Oh.

question: Look, I can start up with him again if you really...
answer: No. I'm doing fine...Look.

question: Good. He's on the world's longest ego trip, let him take it alone.
answer: Hey, okay. Look Buddy -- I've got to go to work.

question: ...good-bye then.
answer: I'll speak to you.

question: You're an amazing woman. What a feeling having you inside my head.
answer: Yeah. It was an unusual place to be.

question: Indescribable -- you knew just when to feed me the next thing, just a split second before I needed it. There was a rhythm we got into, like great sex. You have to celebrate with me, don't you? Everybody's going to that bar on the corner, 'Caps.'
answer: I'm going over to Aaron's. Maybe I'll hoop up with all of you later. How long do you think you'll be there?

question: It's tempting to ask you how you think I did. No. I'm enjoying myself. Take it easy.
answer: Maybe I'll see you over there.

question: You'll never show up. Jane?
answer: Yeah?

question: I'll wait for you till seven.
answer: Okay. Really? It was good. Your calling in that information -- you're the classiest guy I know.

question: Okay. Really? It was good. Your calling in that information -- you're the classiest guy I know.
answer: It was strange to watch him. What's the next step? Lip synching? I've been doing some of the most important thinking of my life. I wonder if this is the right time to tell you about it.

question: Well, whatever you think.
answer: I figured out exactly why it is I'm so hung up on getting a chance at weekend anchor...It's because if I do that well, they'll pay me more, treat me great and my life will be better. That's why.

question: Sounds like you may be on to something.
answer: Which means I'm at their mercy and who wants that?...I'm not going to tell you where this thought led me... Anyway, well, why not tell you? -- it's a happy thing. In the middle of all this I start to think about something that does nothing but make me feel good and makes immediate sense and that's you ...And I'll stop here but, Jane, I'd give anything if you were two people so I could call up the one who's my friend and tell her about the one I'm in I...I don't think I should go any further. Come on -- I'll walk you to the corner.

question: You know you've had a strange day... I'd sleep on all these things you've been thinking.
answer: Absolutely...You go have a good time... You have some place to go?

question: Yes.
answer: Good. Well, I felt something.

question: We're going to Caps Bar at Seventeenth and Vermont; Connecticut is clear on Sunday... take that over to Fifteenth, then around Vermont and we'll bypass the circle that way...if you don't go over forty we should catch mostly green lights. Come on -- don't take it the wrong way. I just know about things. Thanks -- good driving -- Thanks.
answer: I didn't think you'd make it.

question: Well, I thought I'd check if all of you were still here. I'll just go in and join the gang and you two go on.
answer: There's no gang in there -- We were the last ones.

question: Well, I'll go in and have a bite.
answer: Jennifer, you want to have another drink?

question: Thanks for getting me through.
answer: Damn all you sons-of-bitches. Oh shit, you bastards... Sorry.

question: No, it's okay...People say different things. They do...the plural threw me.
answer: The last time I was with someone we went through this awful mutual disease questionnaire but I guess it beats getting paranoid the next day. Okay, I'll go first. I haven't...

question: It would never occur to me to worry at all about you.
answer: You know something? I'm deeply complimented. Isn't it strange to be deeply complimented because the man you're with doesn't think you have a venereal disease?... Give me some of that.

question: Where's the bathroom?
answer: Through the closet. I converted a bedroom -- this stuff builds up. Wait till you've been doing this sixteen years.

question: I'm not knocking it. It's a great solution. Not only the storage but you can see everything you have.
answer: Do you do bunny rabbits?

question: Jennifer. Come on, I'll buy you a drink. There's a big thing over at the Italian embassy.
answer: I'm not sure I'd be good company tonight.

question: I'll be the judge of that. It's much too soon for you to have this kind of buzz around you.
answer: Do I have to stand here in the middle and meet them all?

question: I'll get you through. Move and smile. And smile and move...
answer: Yes. We're fine now.

question: The Italians serve the second best things right after the Chinese...I could do an article comparing Embassy food...Gourmet free-loading...sell it anyplace. I'm sure not getting the assignments.
answer: Who the heck could that be? Is God testing me or something?

question: Paul loves him. I heard him give him the most poetic compliment in his command. 'He's hot.' Sometimes groups of executives get together just to say that work back and forth...'He's hot, oh, she's hot. Oh, he's really hot.' Hot-hot-hot-hot-hot-hot-hot... And here we are.
answer: Martin, you're not allowed to use the word 'we' or I'm moving.

question: Hi, Aaron...What's doing?
answer: Same old stuff. I'm watching a man who won three Overseas Press Awards pitch an hors d'oeuvre idea.

question: You want to go out there -- get out of this for a second?
answer: Why don't you lead? I'll just follow the flurry you cause.

question: What did I do to you?
answer: You've made my dreams silly.

question: Heavy hitters.
answer: How you doing?

question: Great. Network news, Washington... I love it. What do you do when your real life exceeds your dreams?
answer: Keep it to yourself.

question: You know the other day I really wanted your reaction to how we did with the Libyan report -- I was going to ask but I guess I feel a little intimidated with you.
answer: Oh, stop it. You can't talk about feeling intimidated when you're on top of the world. It's unseemly.

question: I'm not buying into any of that. I have a load to learn. I'm not going to act as if...
answer: You have the job you have...

question: Shut up a second...
answer: Okay. Pretty petty party, isn't it, pal?

question: I made one rule for myself when this started and I realized I was going to take a lot from you people because of being from sports...
answer: And the rule was...

question: Never to pretend to know more than I did.
answer: Can you name all the members of the Cabinet?

question: Okay, let's drop it. I didn't mean I'd take a test for you -- I mean if that came up in conversation I'd...
answer: We're conversing...Oh my, the names of the entire Cabinet has slipped my mind. What are they? Don't name them. Just tell me if you know.

question: Yes, Aaron. I know the names of the Cabinet.
answer: Okay.

question: Yes.
answer: There are only ten.

question: You're feeling good, aren't you?
answer: I'm starting to... We may do the capitols of the states.

question: Fifty, right? I'm so exhausted. Punchy. Sick tired. I can't think and I can't move. I'm just a dead lump of poured out flesh. Would you like to come up? Maybe we could just sit here -- talk a little?
answer: Okay. You didn't like the party, huh?

question: Too many smart people in one room -- it's not healthy... I'm going to have to do a story from beginning to end on my own.
answer: Eventually. Does it have to be right now?

question: Believe me, I wouldn't be doing this unless it was absolutely necessary. I have an idea for something.
answer: What?

question: I just read about it in a magazine and it affected me.
answer: Well, what is it?

question: If I tell you, can you manage not to put it down or tell me why it won't work or is in bad journalistic taste or anything like that?
answer: Yes, Tom -- I think I can manage.

question: Hello. Hello...Who is it?
answer: I'm not sure I dialed right -- Jane?

question: Jane, yes. Tom? Tom, is that you? Is this Tom?
answer: Yes.

question: I had to sleep fast so I took two allergy pills to help me...I'm sorry...Hey, you called me.
answer: It's not important.

question: Says who? Not important -- ha-ha-ha. I was dreaming -- Oh, no -- can't tell -- how embarrassing for me. Gosh.
answer: What pills did you take? You sound more like someone on a general anesthetic. Maybe I'd better speak to you tomorrow.

question: Nooo. Is it your story?
answer: No. Are you going to the Correspondents' Dinner on Saturday?

question: Why, you need me for the story?
answer: No. Were you going to you?

question: Uh-huh.
answer: Maybe I'll get off work. I'd like to go.

question: Oh, good.
answer: We can go together.

question: So you like me, huh?
answer: I like you as much as I can like anyone who thinks I'm an asshole. But cops on the street continue to view it as... Shit -- too long. But street cops say...that fits. That last cut work for you, Bobbie?

question: Can I turn on the news for a second? ...Oh, wait a minute. Sex -- Tears -- This must be the news.
answer: The victims often remain too terrified to talk -- the police powerless and all the social welfare groups can finally do is monitor this epidemic of crime without punishment. This is Tom Grunick in Annandale, Virginia.

question: I'm in a pissy mood. I'm sorry.
answer: What's wrong with it?

question: Oh, I was just writing you a note. What do you say we take a walk?
answer: Outside?

question: Yeah -- I don't know if we have any younger man more respected in our operation than you.
answer: Just tell me what's really going on. I think we know each other well enough for me to expect that.

question: We know each other well enough for me to care how I put something to you which could wipe you out. So I will phrase things the way I think they should be phrased. All right?
answer: Wipe me out?

question: Anyway. I want you to think of this as...
answer: Just blunt talk, okay? I'd really appreciate bluntness.

question: Upper management thinks you're dull. Aaron, I've never seen them like this -- I think Paul's nervous about his own job and for some reason he thinks you only appeal to...
answer: Wait. Bullshit me a little...I'm beginning to appreciate it.

question: I'm no suggesting the worst will happen...but someone with your brilliance gets nibbles about other jobs and maybe, the next time that happens, down the road -- you should look into it.
answer: Ah, damn -- the fucking jerks -- My, God. They want to fire me.

question: All I know is that they've got to fire a large number of people... and they're not going by seniority. There's a recklessness in the air. They...
answer: Do one thing to me? Get me one shot at anchoring the Weekend News -- they've never seen me do it. I think it could turn them around.

question: I could do it this Saturday -- everyone wants off for the Correspondents' Dinner.
answer: Do it then.

question: Please prepare carefully. This couldn't come at a better time.
answer: Prepare what? You have Saturday's news handy?

question: It's been a while since you read the news -- I'll have somebody work with you. Just on superficial performance things.
answer: Okay. I think I'd better be alone for a while.

question: I understand. I'll go with you.
answer: Thanks. This is uncomfortable for me -- because, well, I don't mean it as a knock, but we approach this differently.

question: Thanks. This is uncomfortable for me -- because, well, I don't mean it as a knock, but we approach this differently.
answer: We sure do. I don't mean it as a knock either. Go ahead. I'll just say what I think and you can disregard it if you want.

question: It just might not work for me because of our different approaches.
answer: Wait.

question: What?
answer: Your coat jacket is rising up in back. When you sit down -- sit on your jacket a little -- that gives you a good line. Look at yourself in the monitor.

question: I don't like being handled.
answer: Sit on it! Now look.

question: Just don't physically... Fantastic tip -- fantastic.
answer: No. That's not going to tell us anything. Let's get this prompter going.

question: It's not loaded.
answer: I'll find some copy. Be right back. I got copy, I got Ellen to heat up the camera and I got Master Control taping so you can study it later.

question: Hey, Tom... I'm very appreciative.
answer: No. No.

question: No?
answer: Don't let your eyes go from the beginning of the sentence to the end like that. You don't want to look shifty, do you?

question: Oh, God, no!
answer: And the left side of your face is the good one. Go again. And try to punch one word or phrase in every sentence -- punch one idea a story. Punch -- come on -- Good...very nice.

question: Thank you for the compliment, Tom.
answer: Try not to move your head or wrinkle your forehead...this is good, very good... You were smokin' toward the end there.

question: The pointers were great. I'll study the tape.
answer: And remember -- you're not just reading the news or narrating. Everybody has to sell a little. You're selling them this idea of you. You know, what you're sort of saying is, 'trust me. I'm, uh, credible.' So whenever you catch yourself just reading...stop and start selling a little. So long.

question: I spilled some rum on the outfit you picked out. Let me show you the alternates.
answer: Tom...why don't I meet you there? I've got some last minute stuff I've got to take care of...Hey, how did you resolve your dilemma -- did you rent the tux or buy it...I knew it. How much? Wow...Okay...See you there...

question: I didn't know you were going with him.
answer: Did you bring your grey suit?

question: Yes...I was thinking that way too... Which tie?
answer: Thanks. Try this one. I read about it -- that's how you can make sure you don't put on too much perfume...

question: Could you at least pretend that this is an awkward situation for you -- me showing up while you're getting ready for a date.
answer: It's not a date. It's co-workers going to a professional conclave. How long will it tale you to send one?... You look terrific.

question: Really? Because this is important -- so don't just be polite. I'd really like to look...what's the word I'm looking for?...
answer: As good as humanly possible.

question: Yes.
answer: Well, the line of the jacket -- No really....just very nice...just right. I wish I could be there.

question: Me too...Hey...if it gets dull a little before 11:00, drop by the studio.
answer: I'm not sure I'll be able to...I...

question: If...if not, I'll have the tape...I'll wait for you at my apartment.
answer: Okay, great -- good luck.

question: Thanks, Jane. Have a good time tonight.
answer: You too.

question: Want to look at this?
answer: What are you doing here?

question: The weekend news...anchoring... anchoring the weekend news.
answer: Way to go.

question: I'm sorry. I don't want to go in there and sit with everybody. I can't...why don't you go?
answer: Suppose I go in for a little while and you wait in the lobby-bar. How's that?

question: Good. That's it...See you.
answer: Jane. You're not going to take off on me, are you?

question: Twenty seconds. Ten seconds.
answer: How many?

question: Ten.
answer: Okay. Good Evening...In mood and language better suited to an espionage novel than the delicate world of the Western Alliance, the British Foreign Secretary today pounced on what he termed, 'The nest of profession spies and amateur traitors who were turning NATO Headquarters into an instrument whose only true function is folly.' We begin our coverage with Edward Towne in London.

question: Five seconds.
answer: ...the sub-bases referred to are located in five countries... France, Belgium, the Netherlands, Spain as... We well as Great Britain...Our own State Department was rocked not only by the revelation but from the highly unusual persistence from the State Press Corps. Martin Klein reports on the ruckus at Foggy Bottom. Help me.

question: You okay?
answer: Great.

question: Why can't I let go of this woman?
answer: Well... At least kiss me when you do that.

question: You just can't stop editing me. Huh?
answer: This is hysterical. I was half hoping I wouldn't have a good time tonight. You know why?

question: Because you're nuts.
answer: Right, right -- Isn't she fun to tease?

question: More and more lately when I've watched you in action -- seen all your energy -- I've been wondering what it would be like to be inside all that energy.
answer: Right back at you.

question: I don't remember saying anything like that -- exactly...I don't know why I just did.
answer: Oh let's see -- wait a minute, well, I can think of two reasons.

question: What?
answer: Three...I just thought of a third... If you talk about it, you don't have to do it.

question: That's not it.
answer: Good...Another is you're trying to make it all about sex and heat and nothing else. Or it's that great feeling that you don't want to hold anything back. You know, intimacy. Oh, shit. I'm a creep. I forgot all about Aaron. I promised to stop by and see how he did.

question: I'd like to know. I'll go along.
answer: No. I'll see you at your apartment as soon as I can.

question: JANE!
answer: What happened?

question: Don't run off -- like everything's settled the minute you make up your mind.
answer: He might be weird -- he can talk more freely if I go alone -- why's that so hard to understand?

question: It's not that it's hard. I just want you to give me a minute to catch up.
answer: Okay. Sorry. Don't yell at me like that again, you scared the life out of me.

question: Okay. Sorry. Don't yell at me like that again, you scared the life out of me.
answer: I was in the shower.

question: How'd it go?
answer: You didn't see it or speak to anybody?

question: No.
answer: Then it went well.

question: Did it really go well?
answer: Define your terms.

question: Do you feel good about it?
answer: No.

question: Do others feel that you did well?
answer: No.

question: Then what was good about it?
answer: I lost six pounds...

question: Aaron, will you tell me?
answer: It was great...writing my little first rate copy, sitting on my jacket, punching my one thought. But I had this historic attack of flop sweat so they'll never let me another again. Oh, I lost one of your shoulder pads -- how was your evening anyway?

question: What do you mean, flop sweat? -- you're making too much out of it...I'll bet you were the only one aware of it...
answer: People phoned in.

question: Stop kidding. I want to know what happened.
answer: I'm not kidding.

question: There were complaining phone calls because you were sweating?
answer: No, nice ones worried that I was having a heart attack.

question: If all that happened, how come you're so chipper?
answer: I don't know. At a certain point it was so off the chart bad -- it got funny. My central nervous system was telling me something. Jane -- sweat running down my face -- makeup falling into my eyes -- people turning this fusillade of blow dryers on me -- all so I could read introductions to other people who were covering stories which is what I like to do anyway. And I'm chipper because you finally showed up. I thought I'd cook for us. Tequila and eggs sound good?

question: I have to be somewhere. I told what's his name -- Tom -- that I'd meet him.
answer: Call him -- I mean it can wait, right?

question: I don't know. I may be in love with him.
answer: No!!!!! Don't go.

question: This is important to me.
answer: Yeah. Well...I think it is important for you too. Sit down.

question: What?
answer: Let me think a second. It's tough. Aaach...Jane... Let's take the part that has nothing to do with me. Let's let me be your most trusted friend, the one that gets to say awful things to you. You know?

question: Yes, I guess. Yes.
answer: You can't end up with Tom because it goes totally against everything you're about.

question: Yeah -- being a basket case.
answer: I know you care about him. I've never seen you like this about anyone, so please don't take it wrong when I tell you that I believe that Tom, while a very nice guy, is the Devil.

question: This isn't friendship.
answer: What do you think the Devil is going to look like if he's around? Nobody is going to be taken in if he has a long, red, pointy tail. No. I'm semi-serious here. He will look attractive and he will be nice and helpful and he will get a job where he influences a great God-fearing nation and he will never do an evil thing...he will just bit by little bit lower standards where they are important. Just coax along flash over substance... Just a tiny bit. And he will talk about all of us really being salesmen. And he'll get all the great women.

question: I think you're the Devil.
answer: No. You know that I'm not.

question: How?
answer: Because we have the kind of relationship where if I were the Devil, you'd be the only one I told.

question: You were quick enough to get Tom's help when...
answer: Yes, yes. I know. Right. And if it had gone well for me tonight, maybe I'd be keeping quiet about all this...I grant you everything but give me this...he does personify everything you've been fighting against...And I'm in love with you. How do you like that? -- I buried the lead. I've got to not say that aloud; it takes too much out of me.

question: Sit down, stop.
answer: I've never fought for anyone before. Does anybody win one of these things?

question: Hi. It's me.
answer: Where are you?

question: I can't get away just yet. I'm at Aaron's.
answer: Well, when?

question: I'm not sure. It seems like he had sort of a mishap on the news.
answer: I know. I taped it.

question: It wasn't as bad as he think, was it? -- it wasn't unprecedented or anything?
answer: Not if you count 'Singing in the Rain.' Do him a favor and don't treat it like a tragedy. You want me to talk to him?

question: Hi. Will I ever sing again?
answer: Everybody has one like that. I thought it was great when you started to laugh at the end.

question: Yeah -- well, I'm sorry I'm tying up Jane, I didn't realize you two would be going this late. Sorry.
answer: No. Don't worry about it.

question: Hi, again. Sorry about...
answer: No. That sounds more important. Let's forget about tonight.

question: I don't know if that's absolutely necessary.
answer: I've got my father coming through tomorrow anyway. I should get some sleep.

question: Uh-huh.
answer: I'll see you at the office. Good night. Hello?

question: Yes.
answer: Okay. Good night.

question: Good night??!
answer: Jane, I'm not some chore you have to finish so you can stay on schedule.

question: Ernie, they're calling from work.
answer: Tell me I'm on the way in.

question: It's Paul.
answer: Hello. Yes... Would there be any point to my going to New York and talking to them? Would there be any point in going over it with you? No, I'm still coming in.

question: What?
answer: They fired me.

question: How horrible. We'll be fine. You'll be fine. Stay here with me -- we'll go for a drive, have some drinks, make happy plans.
answer: No. They're firing even more people than they said. Some will want to talk. It could help.

question: I could use somebody to talk to on a day like this. Sorry. Go ahead.
answer: Bye, sweetie.

question: Just when do you start, telling people?
answer: Almost immediately.

question: I'd like to take everyone out after the show.
answer: Bill...This is hard on all of us and it's no time for compliments. But I think it's extraordinary of you to come down here for this.

question: I feel terrible about what happened. What did he say?
answer: He -- uh -- said he liked you because you looked like you had -- fire and honesty.

question: No. Did he really?
answer: Yes. Then he said a really weird thing...

question: What?
answer: That it would be a treat to make someone like you feel better... He gets like that sometimes.

question: So I quit.
answer: You packing up tonight?

question: Yes. And I'm sorry that they're sending you down for a while, but you'll make it back...Where they sending you?
answer: London.

question: London. That's a promotion!
answer: I don't think so.

question: It is. Yes -- that's where they had Rorish, for God's sake, before they made him anchor. I can't stand it -- they're grooming you for it all and you don't even know it.
answer: Hold it down, okay?

question: Can I ask you something? You only had one crew on the date rape piece, right?
answer: Yes. You're not going to stick around for the farewell party?

question: No. I don't know how much fun it will be when Martin Klein and Ernie have to drop off their credentials with the security guard. This story they won't cover. And if the network doesn't cover it -- it must not be important so why worry.
answer: I'm going to miss you -- you're a prick in a great way... You know what I...

question: These people -- it's all so awful. It just hurts physically, doesn't it? Like something's wrong with your bones, like your organs are shifting inside your body.
answer: Maybe I haven't been here long enough. But, hey, congratulations on the promotion.

question: How can you say that to me?
answer: Sorry. I can't stand here feeing bad that I don't feel worse. This has happened at every station I ever worked for. Look, I think it's crazy for you to come in here tomorrow and start a new job. I have a week to get to my job. Let's get the hell away to some island fast and find out how we are together away from this.

question: Well, I just think that' an extraordinary proposal.
answer: That's yes?

question: That's more than 'yes' -- that's 'you bet.'
answer: Hello.

question: Bastard, sneak, quitter.
answer: Speaking.

question: I just found out. You didn't say anything to me? You just resign? Will you meet me now? -- No, now! I'm going away tomorrow. Please. Why not try it for a few weeks?
answer: Stop. Ernie thought I was good too -- he couldn't help. My agent has a hot prospect -- the number two station in Portland. The general manager says he wants to be every bit as good as the networks. Personally, I think he should aim higher.

question: Tell me the God's honest truth -- are you leaving because of me? Because if you are...
answer: Ernie told this story. How he used to write obits and when the people in town called him up with death notices, he cried. He was till that way when they promoted him out of obits. He says you're lucky if you can get out while you could still cry. I should have quit this place three years ago.

question: You're just trying to say all great stuff so I'll feel even worse that you're not around.
answer: Let's go...

question: I just want to sit here longer, I mean the feeling is powerful -- why's that?
answer: Maybe the best part of your life is over and you don't want to get up and start the bad part.

question: You are now required to sit here with me. Come on...be smart for a second -- what do you think will happen to us?
answer: Okay, that's very easy. Five, six years from now I'll be in town to collect an award representing the surge in foreign coverage by local stations.

question: Yes.
answer: I'll be walking with my wife and two children -- we'll bump into you on the street, my youngest son will say something and I'll tell him... ...it's not nice to make fun of single, fat ladies.

question: You won't be able to stay mad at me, right?
answer: I hope so... No. I'm not really mad. I'll miss you, we'll talk, we'll always be friends...we'll get hot for each other every few years at dinner and never act on it, okay? Jane, you know how Tom had tears in the piece the other night? Ask yourself how we were able to see them when he only had one camera and that was pointing at the girl during the interview. I'm fairly sure I was right to tell you.

question: ...but the whole thing messed me up more than it should.
answer: That's enough. That's enough.

question: I'm sorry.
answer: Are you okay?

question: Yes, I'm sorry.
answer: Don't be silly. What are you sorry about?

question: The way you were looking at me, I just went.
answer: I just need you for another minute now, so we can shoot from behind towards me, and, um...

question: Uh-huh.
answer: ...that way we have someplace to go when we cut. And I just sit here, I nod my head and look nerdy. Yeah. Really? Then give me a minute...

question: ...that way we have someplace to go when we cut. And I just sit here, I nod my head and look nerdy. Yeah. Really? Then give me a minute...
answer: You fucking...

question: Look who's the organized one. I've got everything.
answer: I'm not going.

question: Why?
answer: I saw the taped outtakes of the interview with the girl. I know you 'acted' your reaction after the interview.

question: I felt funny about it afterwards. It's verboten, huh? I thought since I did it for real the first time -- but I get you. That's not the reason you're not coming?
answer: Of course it's the reason. It's terrible what you did.

question: We disagree on how God-awful it was. Why don't you come with me and we can disagree and get a tan at the same time?
answer: Jesus, if you're glib about this I'm going to lose it. I was up all night and...

question: Jane, Jane, Jane, Jane, Jane...
answer: It made me ill. You could get fired for things like that.

question: I got promoted for things like that.
answer: Working up tears for a new piece cutaway...You totally crossed the line between...

question: It's hard not to cross it; they keep moving the little sucker, don't they?
answer: It just proves that the difference we have are...

question: This is a one-way argument. We've got six days; if you go and we fight and we hate it -- we'll come home. If you don't go? Well, that's a much bigger deal. I go to London right after that. So, it'd be very big deal if you stay here. The plane's boarding. You're good at deadline. Here's your ticket.
answer: It's amazing. You commit this incredible breach of ethics and you act as if I'm nitpicking. Try and get this. When you edited that...

question: I'm leaving now. Gate 43.
answer: That's not going to be the way we say good-bye. Even though I think what you did was rotten -- it's not all impersonal. You mean something to me.

question: You keep coming after me and looking down on me. It's starting to make me batty.
answer: I don't wan to discuss work.

question: Well, let's do a special report on that...I mean that's news.
answer: I knew what you meant.

question: What I don't know, I can learn and what I know, nobody can teach. Excuse me for saying it about myself, but I think it's true. What do you think? Never mind what you think.
answer: You're lucky I came after you so you got that off your...

question: Yes, I am. Thanks. I mean it.
answer: It's okay. So you have an extra bathing suit, huh?

question: You want to come?
answer: It's just that one of the few things I'm not confused about is what I was saying downstairs, that...

question: Then you should stay here.
answer: It's better when you let me say it.

question: Take it easy.
answer: Why did I have to do this to myself? Watch you take off. Call me if you need anything.

question: Holy shit, Aaron. Lila -- this is Aaron Altman.
answer: Hi.

question: Well, this kid couldn't possibly belong to anyone else. What's your name?
answer: Do you know who this is, Cliff? I'm just bringing him over to give Jane a look at him --

question: I thought she'd be here. I'll go with you.
answer: Okay.

question: I'll see you back at the hotel.
answer: Oh, I didn't say anything about your speech.

question: I'm going to take it.
answer: What a great surprise. I didn't think we had a chance. I heard you wanted to stay in Washington.

question: Well, there's a guy, but he says he'll fly up a lot.
answer: Well, we should talk. You going to have time for dinner? I'd like you to meet Lila.

question: I'm sorry because I was looking forward to that, but I' m going back in a few hours.
answer: Okay...It's so good to see you. It's nice to see you.
